categories.name: Mythical Creatures from Around the World

questions.clue: This fire-breathing creature from European folklore is often depicted as a large, winged reptile.
In Greek mythology, this half-man, half-bull creature was kept in the labyrinth by King Minos.
Known as 'Kappa' in Japan, these water spirits are said to have a dish on their head containing water.
This creature from Hindu mythology has the head of an elephant and is known as the remover of obstacles.
In Norse mythology, this serpent, also called the Midgard Serpent, is so large it encircles the world.
This artist painted the 'Mona Lisa', one of the most famous portraits in the world.
Commissioned by Pope Julius II, this artist painted the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel.
Known for his 'School of Athens', this artist was part of the High Renaissance.
This early Renaissance artist is famed for his frescoes in the Brancacci Chapel.
This Florentine artist's work 'The Birth of Venus' is a hallmark of the Italian Renaissance.
This principle, formulated by Werner Heisenberg, states that you cannot simultaneously know both the position and momentum of a particle with absolute precision.
This is the name of the theoretical particle that carries electromagnetic force, also known as a particle of light.
The famous thought experiment involving a cat, a box, and a radioactive atom is attributed to this physicist.
Named after an Austrian physicist, this equation describes how the quantum state of a physical system changes with time.

This phenomenon occurs when two particles become correlated in such a way that the quantum state of one cannot be described independently of the state of the other, no matter the distance between them.
This novel begins, 'It was the best of times, it was the worst of times...'
The first line, 'Call me Ishmael,' is from this classic sea adventure.
Identify the book that starts with 'All happy families are alike; each unhappy family is unhappy in its own way.'
A dystopian novel opens with 'It was a bright cold day in April, and the clocks were striking thirteen.'
'The sun shone, having no alternative, on the nothing new' is the first line of this postmodern novel.
Originating from Mexico, these corn tortillas are filled with a variety of meats and topped with onions and cilantro.
Popular in Thailand, this stir-fried noodle dish often includes shrimp, tofu, peanuts, and a tangy tamarind sauce.
This Japanese street food features octopus-filled batter balls, often topped with bonito flakes and mayonnaise.
Found in the Middle East, this deep-fried ball made of ground chickpeas or fava beans is often served in a pita.
Hailing from China, this street food consists of skewered, spiced, and grilled lamb, known for its cumin and chili flavor.

final.clue: Published in 1949, this novel introduced the concept of 'Big Brother' and was meant as a warning about totalitarianism.
